introduction.p: You may have heard, The world is constantly changing. But the big question is How? Is there a pattern? In math, patterns have names.
Linear is the name of a pattern. A linear equationlinearequation may look like this y=mx+b and its graph is a straight line.
If you look at the data from a linear patternLinearpattern you will notice the data has a constant rate of change, in other words constant slope.

In this section we study a pattern in which something remains constant, but it's not the rate of change, it is the percent change. An exponential patternexponentialpattern has the characteristic of constant percent change.

subsection.title: Percent Change, Multiplication and the Growth Factor
subsection.p: Before we explore exponential functions, we should have a very good understanding of percent, what it means and how it is calculated.
Students may need a more in-depth review on the meanings of the terms decimal equivalent and growth factor. Follow this link to an interactive review of that material: review
In short, to change a number by a percent, we multiply.
For instance if we start with the number 8, then 8\cdot 1.25 means to increase the number 8 by one and a quarter of itself. You get all of the 8 and 25 \% more.
8\cdot 1.25 = 10 means that 10 is 25 \% greater than 8
On the other hand, if we again start with 8 then 8\cdot 0.75 is a fraction of 8. Not all of it, only a portion. In fact, it means 75 \% of 8.
Notice that keeping 75 \% of 8 automatically means a loss of 25 \%. The equation 8\cdot 0.75 = 6 says 6 is 75 \% of 8 which also means 6 is 25 \% less than 8.
The number we multiply by to get the percent change is called the growth factorgrowth factor even though it may actually result in a percent decrease.
In this book we will refer to the growth factor with the variable b.

example.p: Given an initial value of 165, identify the growth factor b:

li.p: The expression 165(1.12) has a growth factor b = 1.12
The expression 165(0.081) has a growth factor b = 0.081
The expression 165(5.69) has a growth factor b = 5.69

introduction.p: Use the growth factor to determine the percent change on the given initial value. The growth factor is shown in parentheses.

li.p: Given 22(1.39) what is the percent change on the initial value of 22?
Given 7(2.41) what is the percent change on the initial value of 7?
Given 17(0.56) what is the percent change on the initial value of 17?

solution.p: The growth factor is actually composed of 1 \pm r where r is the decimal equivalent of the percent gain or loss.
A percent increase implies the growth factor b = 1 + r, (i.e. b \gt 1) while a percent decrease implies b=1-r, (i.e. 0 \lt b \lt 1).

li.p: Since the growth factor b = 1.39 is greater than 1 we have 1+r = 1.39. Solving for r we get r=1.39-1 = 0.39. This is the decimal equivalent of a 39 \%percent increase.
Since the growth factor b = 2.41 is greater than 1 we have 1+r = 2.41. Solving for r we get r=2.41-1 = 1.41. This is the decimal equivalent of a 141 \%percent increase.
Since the growth factor b = 0.56 is less than 1 we have 1-r = 0.56. Solving for r we get r=1-0.56=0.44. This is the decimal equivalent of a 44 \%percent decrease.

subsection.title: Linear vs. Exponential Patterns
subsection.p: Looking at data, lists of numbers, is part of almost everyone's profession. We search for patterns in the data from past or current events to try to predict future events. We have questions, like

li.p: How long will a mechanical part last?
When can we administer the next dose of medication?
When will we get to our destination?

subsection.p: Two common patterns are linear and exponential. The news is full of them.

p.em: Exponential gains in computing power, along with innovations in software, analytical techniques and the rise of Big Data, mean that many white-collar occupations are due for disruption by machines too. According to a 2013 study by two Oxford University professors, almost half of all jobs in the United States are susceptible to “computerization” over the coming decade or two.

blockquote.p: How Efficiency Is Wiping Out the Middle Class, Another View by David Diegel, New York Times January 25, 2017

example.p: In writing, Exponential gains in computing power this article claims computing power is increasing by a constant percent. It must be assumed that the increases happen over equal time intervals, like every year or every 10 years for the claim to be valid.

p.em: In 2012 the average rent was $2,225. Every year it has risen roughly a hundred dollars. But in late 2016, the rental market suddenly became flat.

If I were to bet, I would bet that prices are on the way down. I would bet the tenants and buyers are going to have the upper hand probably for the next two or three years, said real estate broker Peter Zalewski.

blockquote.p: After Years Of Price Hikes, South Florida's Rental Market Entering New Era Of Decline, David Sutta, CBS Miami, March 29, 2017

example.p: This article is reporting a pattern of constant rate of change (monthly rent). The real estate broker quoted in the article is using a linear model to predict the rental market for the next two or three years.

subsection.p: Distiguishing between linear and exponential patterns is as easy as knowing the difference between addition and multipication. The patterns allow us to find formulas for linear or exponential situations.
A linear patternlinear patternconstant rate of change of constant rate of change is essentially repeated addition. A linear formula counts how many times you add the same number.
An exponential patternexponentialpattern of constant percent change is essesntially repeated multiplication. An exponential formula counts how many times you multiply by the same number.

subsection.title: A General Formula for Exponential Growth/Decay: Discrete Model

assemblage.p: You will find the word compounded in the exercises that follow.

Compoundingcompounding is the process of repeatedly increasing or decreasing by a percent. It refers to the fact each succesive percent change is based on a number already greater/lesser than the original.

li.p: Compounded monthly means a percent is calculated each month.
Compounded annually means a percent is calculated each year.
In the expression 500\cdot 1.15\cdot 1.15\cdot 1.15 the value 500 has been compounded three times by 15 \%.

subsection.p: Now we have general forms for both linear y=mx+b and exponential y=ab^{x} equations.

In the linear equation y=mx+b the variable b is sometimes referred to as the initial value. On a graph it represents the vertical intercept while m represents the rate of change (slope). The rate of change tells us the rate of increase (or decrease) per unit input.
The variable x counts how many times the rate of change is added to the initial value.
In the exponential equation y = ab^{x} the initial value is represented by a, and b is the growth factor. This equation, or model, is called the discrete exponential model.
The growth factor tells us the percent increase (or decrease) per unit input while the variable x in this case counts how many times the growth factor is multiplied.
Finding the growth factor per unit in an exponential formula can be tricky. We have been thinking in terms of linear (constant rate of change)for so long, we often think everything is linear.

We need a way to convert a statement like 60 \% over 3 years into one about the percent growth per year. A good start is to remind ourselves how repeated addition is different than repeated multiplication.
